fields.Acute_plan:
##Abdominal pain
Check for signs of peritonitis in physical exam
Passing gas? Bowel movement? 
Check KUB xrays for bowel obstruction
Can order simethicone for gas pain

##Antibiotics
Do not reorder antibiotics overnight before checking with primary team or attending, especially for spine patients. 
~~In most cases, antibiotics can wait until morning
~~The only time you should acutely begin antibiotics is for post-operative 24h antibiotics, in case these were missed.
Red man syndrome from vancomycin
~~Benadryl and ranitidine premedication. Tachy at baseline, no hypotension.

##Chest pain
Always get a EKG
History of MI or PE?
If persistent 

##Compartment syndrome
Stryker needle?

##Dressing
Aquacell came off - repaint with chloraprep, get a new Aquacell from OR, then put one back on

##DVT
Consult Dr. Sidagam
First start on anti-coagulation with Lovenox

##Pain control

##Urinary issues
Dysuria? Ordered UA.
Urinary retention? Follow post-void residuals, then foley if retention does not resolve after straight cath x2.

##Ask on the phone:
Weapon type: 
~~Handgun (low velocity)
~~Shotgun (intermediate velocity)
~~Assault rifle (high velocity, treat like Gustilo Type III)
Near a joint? Need to ask for CT to check for intra-articular fragments.

##Ask on the phone:
Make NPO
What antibiotics?
~~Gustilo type I and II - ancef
~~Gustilo type III - ancef + gentamicin
~~Farm injuries, heavy contamination, or bowel injuries - ancef + gentamicin + penicillion (clostridium coverage)
~~Fresh water - ceftazidime/cipro
~~Ssalt water - doxycycline + ceftazidime/cipro
~~GSW from handgun - ancef
Tetanus PPX?
AP/laterals of extremities involved

##What to get before seeing consult:
4x4 gauze and ABD pads
Lac repair kit
18g needle
Sterile normal saline

##Physical exam/further imaging:
ABI: If pulses aren't palpable manually or Dopplerable.
Saline load test, anytime there is a laceration over joint. 95% sensitivity: 
~~194cc in knee
~~40cc in elbow
~~30cc in ankle 

##Interventions in ED:
Direct pressure for hemostasis: Controls most bleeding, no need for tourniquet.
Cover in saline-soaked gauze: no evidence for aggressive washout in ED, as it can push debris inward.
Splint: To decrease pain, minimize soft tissue trauma, and stabilize clots.

##If operative, perform before calling PGY-4/attending:

##Ask on the phone:
Labs? 
~~ESR (90% sensitive, up in acute and chronic)
~~CRP (97% sensitive)
~~WBC (33% sensitive)
~~Blood cultures (usually neg, but good if hematogenous spread)
XR: 
~~Always get them, but findings only apparent after 2 weeks. 
~~Will show bone lucency, osteopenia, periosteal reaction, lysis around hardware.

##Physical exam/further imaging:
Symptom timing? Acute (within 2 weeks), subacute (1-several months), chronic (several months)
CT: If nothing on XR, get CT to better visualize necrotic bone
MRI: If nothing on XR and CT, get MRI. Negative rules out osteomyelitis.
Check for sinus tract: If able to probe bone through sinus tract, chronic OM present.

##Wrap-up, if non-operative or outpatient surgery:
Majority of the time, will just need admission to medicine for IV abx for acute OM. Even if going to OR, will need 24-48 hrs IV abx. 

##Wrap-up, if operative:
Admit to ortho and post for I&D in OR: If draining sinus tract is present.

##Ask on the phone:
Make NPO
As soon as you get the call, be sure they have ordered CBC, ESR, CRP, and plain films of the joint. 
Serum lab values associated with septic joint:
~~WBC > 10K with left shift
~~ESR > 30
~~CRP > 5
Most will NOT be septic joint. HOWEVER, all must be treated as septic joint and seen urgently. Prioritize these consults. 

##What to get before seeing consult:
Aspiration supplies:
~~Sterile urine specimen cup
~~18-20 gauge needles
~~30-60cc syringe
~~Chloraprep sticks/swabs
~~Specimen bag
~~Pt sticker for specimen cup (sterile urinalysis cup)
~~Culture swab
~~Print lab requisition forms for cell count/gram stain/crystals/cultures (lab won't perform analysis without these orders on physical documents) 

##Physical exam/further imaging:
Take picture of infection
Check for draining sinus tract
~~Tract confirms infection, no need to aspirate
~~No need to swab or culture tract, too contaminated to be helpful
Assess for pain with ROM. Painless PASSIVE or active ROM suggests less likely septic. 

##Interventions in ED:
Generally, if there is ANY concern (elevated inflamm markers and some pain), the attending will prefer that you aspirate the joint. 
~~After aspiration, transfer aspirate to the specimen cup. 
~~Apply pt sticker and be sure to sign, date, and time the specimen on the sticker (lab will refuse otherwise).
If you get minimal aspirate (~1cc):
~~Cell count can’t be performed, but the swab can be used for gram stain/culture. 
~~On lab requisition sheet, write 'PRIORITIZE gram stain/culture, get crystals/cell count only if possible.' 
~~Squirt the aspirate into the swab container in this situation.
Joint fluid is LIQUID GOLD. ALWAYS walk the specimen to the lab yourself and physically hand it to a lab tech at the window. NEVER use tube system.
Analyze cell count/diff, gram stain and culture, and crystals.
Wait until ALL of this information is back (gram stain is usually last) before calling 4. Even with crystals, there is a small chance of superinfection, so must have gram stain.

##If operative, perform before calling PGY-4/attending:
Review indications for acute surgery:
~~Aspirate WBC >50K is indicate of infection
Mark/Consent for surgery: Irrigation and debridement, possible implant exchange, of <joint> arthroplasty with possible antibiotic spacer placement. 
Make copy of consent and place original in chart. Make sure to put copy in call room or give it to next call resident.
Keep NPO and NWB.
Find out OR availability: Call to ask for OR availability today and tomorrow.
Ask for clearance. For details, refer to pre-operative clearance guide.
~~ If overnight, call anesthesia.
~~ If during the day and with multiple comorbidities, or for syncopal fall, call medicine.
~~ If trauma activation, call trauma.
~~ If patient goes to ICU, ask for clearance again in morning: These patients have to be reassessed every AM, as their stability may change.
Determine operative options:
~~I&D w/ polyethylene exchange vs two-stage revision (immediate removal of hardware and antibiotic spacer insertion, followed by later revision)
~~Refer to orthobullets for details. If <3 weeks after surgery, can just do I&D. If >4 weeks, must do two-stage revision.
Call reps: Call the implant maker from the OP report. All rep numbers in our phone bank.

##Wrap-up, if operative:
Call attending: Tell them SBAR, OR schedule
Post case: Tell them name, MRN, attending doing surgery, positioning and operative set-up, implant

##Wrap-up, if non-operative/not immediately operative:
Follow up with attending who did the surgery

~~Meets SIRS criteria

Call attending: Tell them SBAR, OR schedule

##Wrap-up, if non-operative/not immediately operative:
Follow up with attending who did the surgery

##Ask on the phone:
Get plain films of bone involved 

##Physical exam/further imaging:
Assess for any pain 

##Wrap-up:
Pure AVNs never need acute surgery, unless it's hardware failure
Let attending know about it and follow up with the attending on call

##Ask on the phone:
~~Adequate x-rays (entire bone, joint above and below); 
~~Do they have a primary cancer diagnosis? Any known bony mets?
~~NPO time

##What to get before seeing consult:
~~Consent: Prophylactic fixation of [bone] vs. Operative fixation of pathologic [bone] fracture
~~Confirm not pathologic fracture before seeing, as this changes how patient will be managed in ED

##Physical exam/further imaging:
Known primary? If tumor of unknown origin, needs:
~~MRI of entire bone: Getty likes to get MRIs but you should talk to 4th year before getting MRI but when you call 4th year it is something to discuss; Always put “tumor protocol” in special instructions
~~CT C/A/P
~~SPEP/UPEP
First bony met? If this is first bony metastasis, needs an IR guided biopsy prior to prophylactic fixation
Lytic vs blastic? Pathologic fracture or not?

##Wrap-up:
Admit to Medicine for tumor workup

##Ask on the phone:
AP/lat shoulder
Axillary view if patient can tolerate it, Velpau view if patient can't tolerate axillary
CT shoulder to look for bony injuries

##What to get before seeing consult:
Supplies for an intraarticular block

##Physial exam/further imaging:
Load and shift
Apprehension sign
Sulcus sign

##Interventions in the ED:
Collier Technique (for Anterior Dislocation)
~~Patient laying down. 
~~Adduct the arm, externally rotate arm very slowly, as much as they can tolerate.  
~~Feel humeral head on top of glenoid. Push on it while abducting the arm.

Joanne Technique (for Anterior Dislocation): external rotation, flexion, have them touch their other shoulder

##If reduction not successful:
Make sure CT is available for bony lesions
M/C/P for closed reduction of shoulder in OR

##Wrap-up, if reduction successful:
Place in sling, follow-up with attending on call

##Ask on the phone:
AP, lateral of humerus
AP, lateral, axillary/velpeau view of shoulder
Place in a sling

##Physical exam/further imaging
Neurovascular exam:
~~Check axillary nerve motor and sensory function
~~Check radial nerve function
Ask ED to get CT if articular surface is involved

##If operative, perform before calling PGY-4/attending:
Review indications for acute surgery:
~~Any neurovascular compromise
~~Greater trochanter displacement > 5mm - unstable rotator cuff
~~Displaced anatomic/surgical neck fractures - more instability? 
~~Transverse fracture at surgical neck - more chance for displacement
~~Head-splitting fracture - due to articular surface involvement
~~3 or 4 part proximal humerus fracture - essentially comminuted and unstable
Mark/Consent for surgery: Open reduction internal fixation vs intramedullary nailing of proximal humerus 
Make copy of consent and place original in chart. Make sure to put copy in call room or give it to next call resident.
Keep NPO and NWB.
Find out OR availability: Call to ask for OR availability today and tomorrow.
Ask for clearance. For details, refer to pre-operative clearance guide.
~~ If overnight, call anesthesia.
~~ If during the day and with multiple comorbidities, or for syncopal fall, call medicine.
~~ If trauma activation, call trauma.
~~ If patient goes to ICU, ask for clearance again in morning: These patients have to be reassessed every AM, as their stability may change.
Plan needed implants and operative approach/intervals/set-up:
~~ Will need DepuySynthes vs Stryker ORIF vs IMN sets.
~~ For ORIF, will need a low profile precontoured locking plate, placed through a deltopectoral approach. Patient should be supine on radiolucent OR table with arm board and C-arm, with bed rotated 90 degrees so that the injured shoulder is opposite the anesthesia team.
~~ For IMN, will need a short/long nail placed through a deltoid-splitting approach. Patient should be spine on radiolucent OR table with arm board and C-arm, with bed rotated 90 degrees so that the injured shoulder is opposite the anesthesia team. 
~~ For hemiarthroplasty, place implant through deltopectoral approach. Patient should be spine on radiolucent OR table with arm board and C-arm, with bed rotated 90 degrees so that the injured shoulder is opposite the anesthesia team. 
Call reps: Call Stryker or DepuySynthes. All rep numbers in our phone bank.

##Wrap-up, if operative:
Call attending: Tell them SBAR, OR schedule
Post case: Tell them name, MRN, attending doing surgery, positioning and operative set-up, implant

##Wrap-up, if non-operative/not immediately operative:
Recommend NWB in sling, follow up with attending on call.

##Ask on the phone:
AP, lateral of humerus - Any lytic lesions? Signs of pathologic fracture?
AP, lateral, axillary/velpeau view of shoulder - Shoulder dislocation?
AP, lateral of elbow - Elbow dislocation?
AP, lateral of forearm - Check for forearm fracture to rule out 'floating elbow'

##What to get before seeing consult:
Supplies for coaptation splint
Post-splint AP/lat humerus - put this in now so you don't forget later

##Physical exam/further imaging:
Neurovascular exam: Check radial nerve function

##Interventions in ED:
Place in coaptation splint
~~Place in valgus mold to counteract pull of deltoid muscle - medial force on proximal fragment, lateral force on distal fragment
~~These will always drift distally, so make sure to place proximal end way past the acromion, almost to the level of the neck
~~Parameters for acceptable reduction: <20 deg AP angulation, <30 deg valgus/varus angulation, <3cm shortening 

##If operative, perform before calling PGY-4/attending:
Review indications for acute surgery:
~~Ipsilateral forearm fracture - 'floating elbow', since elbow is disconnected from both elbow and arm, so needs to be reattached to humerus
~~Pathologic fracture
~~Any neurovascular compromise - brachial plexus injury only, radial palsy alone is NOT indication for surgery
~~Compartment syndrome/open fractures
~~Polytrauma - patient will need arm for mobilization
Mark/Consent for surgery: Open reduction internal fixation vs intramedullary nailing of humerus
Make copy of consent and place original in chart. Make sure to put copy in call room or give it to next call resident.
Keep NPO and NWB.
Find out OR availability: Call to ask for OR availability today and tomorrow.
Ask for clearance. For details, refer to pre-operative clearance guide.
~~ If overnight, call anesthesia.
~~ If during the day and with multiple comorbidities, or for syncopal fall, call medicine.
~~ If trauma activation, call trauma.
~~ If patient goes to ICU, ask for clearance again in morning: These patients have to be reassessed every AM, as their stability may change.
Plan needed implants and operative approach/intervals/set-up:
~~ Will need DepuySynthes vs Stryker ORIF vs IMN sets.
~~ For ORIF, will need a low profile precontoured locking plate, placed through a deltopectoral approach. Patient should be supine on radiolucent OR table with arm board and C-arm, with bed rotated 90 degrees so that the injured shoulder is opposite the anesthesia team.
~~ For IMN, will need a long nail placed through a deltoid-splitting approach. Patient should be spine on radiolucent OR table with arm board and C-arm, with bed rotated 90 degrees so that the injured shoulder is opposite the anesthesia team. 
Call reps: Call Stryker or DepuySynthes. All rep numbers in our phone bank.

##Wrap-up, if operative:
Call attending: Tell them SBAR, OR schedule
Post case: Tell them name, MRN, attending doing surgery, positioning and operative set-up, implant

##Wrap-up, if non-operative/not immediately operative:
NWB in coaptation splint, follow up with attending on call.

##Ask on the phone:
NPO - high chance of acute surgery
AP, lateral elbow
AP, lateral of humerus - for possible operative planning
AP, lateral forearm
~~To rule out 'floating elbow'
~~Check for olecranon fractures - may complicate Chevron olecranon osteotomy during surgery. Total elbow arthroplasty also needs intact olecranon
CT elbow w/ 3D recon - to assess for intra-articular involvement and help operative planning

##What to get before seeing consult:
Post-splint AP/lat elbow - do this now so you don't forget later 
Material for posterior long arm splint

##Physical exam/further imaging:
Classify fracture:
~~OTA Type A, B, C
~~Milch Type I or II
DO NOT range elbow, to avoid risk of further neurovascular injury
Neuro exam:
~~Check axillary nerve motor and sensory function
~~Check radial nerve function
Vascular exam:
~~Doppler radial/ulnar pulses - high chance of disruption since brachial artery is very near distal humerus. 
~~Ask ED to consult vascular surgery if there's any abnormality in pulses
If >2 fragments, get traction view
~~Much better than CT in defining fragments.
~~Have low threshold for getting one

##Intereventions in the ED:
Place in posterior long arm splint

##If operative, perform before calling PGY-4/attending:
Review indications for acute surgery:
~~Consider all distal humerus fractures as operative, except maybe non-displaced Type C fractures. Don't waste time studying indications and trying to sound smart.
Mark/Consent for surgery: Open reduction internal fixation vs elbow arthroplasty, possible perctaneous pinning, of distal humerus
Make copy of consent and place original in chart. Make sure to put copy in call room or give it to next call resident.
Keep NPO and NWB.
Find out OR availability: Call to ask for OR availability today and tomorrow.
Ask for clearance. For details, refer to pre-operative clearance guide.
~~ If overnight, call anesthesia.
~~ If during the day and with multiple comorbidities, or for syncopal fall, call medicine.
~~ If trauma activation, call trauma.
~~ If patient goes to ICU, ask for clearance again in morning: These patients have to be reassessed every AM, as their stability may change.
Plan needed implants and operative approach/intervals/set-up:
~~ Will need small-fragment set.
~~ For ORIF, will need 3.5mm DCP or pelvic recon plates, placed through a a posterior Chevron olecranon osteotomy, with patient placed in lateral decupitus and a radiolucent arm board.   

##Wrap-up, if operative:
Call attending: Tell them SBAR, OR schedule
Post case: Tell them name, MRN, attending doing surgery, positioning and operative set-up, implant

##Wrap-up, if non-operative/not immediately operative:
Rarely will be the case, only for truly Type C supracondylar fracture
NWB in splint, follow up with attending on call.

##Ask on the phone:
Open? Bite marks?
AP/lateral hand, wrist

##Physical exam/further imaging:
Neurovascular status
Check for fight bite
Scissoring?

##Interventions in the ED:
Jahss maneuver for reduction of Boxer’s fx under hematoma block
Ulnar gutter for 4th or 5th metacarpals. Make sure you’re splinting one digit radial and ulnar to the injured finger!
For 2nd and 3rd can do radial gutter or just do dorsal and volar slab

##Wrap-up:
Follow-up with attending on call.

##Ask on the phone:
AP/lateral XRs to assess for underlying fracture
Ancef/tetanus?
Lidocaine at bedside for digital block
Volar or dorsal?

##What to get before seeing consult:
Lac repair kit
Non-absorvable suture (tendon injury) and rapidly absorving suture (skin closure)
Split material

##Physical exam/further imaging:
Check for any exposed tendons or bone
If hand, identify flexor or extensor zones
Neurovascular exam:
~~Modified Allen test, Doppler signals
~~Median, radial, ulnar, digital nerves
Tendon exam:
~~Tenodesis exam
~~Hold other fingers straight when testing flexion as FDP typically have shared muscle belly

##Interventions in ED:
For dorsal tendon injuries:
~~Repair in ED, if >60% observed with loupe or patient has limited extension (after radial block to eliminate pain)
~~Used braided nonabsorvable suture in a figure-of-eight stitch, keeping knot-bulk to a minimum
~~Place in volar splint to prevent flexion and repair failure

For flexor tendon injuries:
~~DO NOT repair in ED, needs to go to OR given the higher risk of damaging neurovascular structures
~~Irrigate the laceration, loosely approximate the skin, and splint hand in slight flexion to bring tendon edges closer together

##Wrap-up, if operative:
Nerve injuries must be repaired acutely in the OR

##Wrap-up, if non-operative:
Send home on Keflex x7 days

##Ask on the phone:
X-ray of digit to assess for underlying fracture
NPO status/sedation time (ED HATES sedating for this)
Ancef/tetanus?

##What to get before seeing consult:
5.0 or 4.0 absorbable suture (chromic), 4.0 non-absorbable suture, dermabond
Lidocaine for nerve block
Laceration kit at bedside
18 gauge needle for possible nail trephination, if subungual hematoma present

##Physical exam/further imaging:
Complete exam – sensation (ulnar and radial digital nerve exam), motor (tendons involved?)

##Interventions in the ED
Subungual hematoma:
~~If <50% of nail, there is risk of nail bed injury, but okay to just trephine nail with 18gauze
~~If >50% of nail, high risk of nail bed injury, so remove nail and inspect nailbed

Nailbed laceration repair:
~~After digital nerve block, remove nail (using freer borrowed from OR / a blunt, rounded edge of scissors in suture tray). 
~~Irrigate the nailbed laceratiion and repair with 6-0 or 5-0 (if 6-0 keeps breaking) chromic (ALWAYS ABSORBABLES) with simple sutures then use dermabond to stick everything together. 
~~For simple, small lacerations, just dermabond is fine.
~~After dermabond dries, replace the nail on the fold after sterilizing in betadine and rinsing. 
~~Suture nail in place with 5-0 chromic at the two proximal and two distal corners of the nailfold. Can use folded aluminum foil or folded xeroform if nail damaged/lost. 
~~Dress in xeroform and a bulky dressing (2x2s, nonadhesize gauze), held in place with tape.

##Wrap-up:
~~Make sure patient got ancef/tetanus in ED, send home on Keflex x 7 days
~~Staff and follow-up with attending on call

##Ask on the phone:
Plain films to assess for underlying fracture and/or level of amp
Ancef/tetanus?

##What to get before seeing consult:
Rongeur and scrub brush from OR

##Physical exam/further imaging:
Complete exam – sensation, motor (tendons involved?)
THOROUGHLY irrigate wound (can take 1L NS bottle and poke holes on front of bottle with 18g needle to make squirt bottle) to better evaluate. 
Snap photos for documentation and to show PGY4/attending.

##Interventions in the ED:
Grab a sterile glove, cut off the finger of the glove, and roll onto the finger to act as a tourniquet or get a finger tourniquet from the suture cart. (DON’T FORGET TO CUT IT OFF WHEN YOU’RE DONE!!!) 
Once films and clinical photos obtained, call the PGY4 to discuss. If formal revision amp required, irrigate and re-dress the wound with xeroform, 2x2s, and cling gauze until OR. 
For bedside revision, ask PGY4 for recs: 
~~Rongeur can be obtained from OR. Don’t damage the FDP insertion in the proximal phalanx.
~~Whenever you use a Rongeur, wear eye protection!!!
~~After revision amp, use an OR scrub brush and go to town cleaning it. Then take a picture and send to attending. It helps them a lot in clinic

##Wrap-up, if operative:
Mark/Consent for revision amputation

##Wrap-up, if non-operative:
Make sure patient received IV Abx (at least 1 dose) and homegoing PO course (likely Keflex) x7 days. 
Follow up with attending on call.

##Ask on the phone:
URGENT consult!! 
Plain films, CBC, ESR, CRP

##Physical exam/further imaging:
Knavel’s signs:
~~1) fusiform swelling of entire digit
~~2) digit held preferentially flexed
~~3) pain with passive stretch
~~4) TTP over FTS
Unsure of dx? TTP in the palm proximal to the digit is HIGHLY suggestive of FTS

##Interventions in the ED:
Start broad-spectrum IV abx. 
Depending on exam, pt may be monitored and elevated (hanging arm splint) or may require formal I&D. 

##Wrap-up:
Once a physical exam, IV abx, and pictures are obtained, d/w PGY4.

##Ask on the phone:
AP, lateral, open-mouth odontoid XRs
~~Rarely helpful to assess condylar injuries because maxilla and occiput block condyles, mainly for seeing associated injuries.
CT neck and cervical spine - method of choice.

##Physical exam/further imaging:
Conduct neuro exam: full upper and lower extremities, saddle anesthesia, rectal tone, long tract signs (clonus, hyperreflexia, Babinski, Hoffman's) 
Calculate Powels ratio: 
~~From CT. Distance from basion to posterior arch / Distance from anterior arch to opisthion 
~~1 normal, <1 posterior occipitocervical dislocation, >1 anterior occipitocervical dislocation.
Calculate basion-dens interval: 
~~From CT. >12mm indicates disassociation.
Get Anderson classification: For occipitocervical fractures. Type I,II,III.
Consider MRI: 
~~For any neuro deficits.
~~Get if CT shows fracture retropulsion into canal or CT findings suspicious for ligamentous injury (widening of condyle spaces, etc.). 
~~Discuss with senior before ordering.

Likely will be admitted to trauma: Considered high energy injury, recommend Aspen collar and observation for 24hrs

NATIVE: NATIVE is an EMERGENT consult. Time out of joint puts stress on capital femoral blood supply and risks AVN.

##Ask on the phone:
When did dislocation happen?
Needs emergent sedation and closed reduction after confirmation on PLAIN FILM. Do NOT get CT before reduction.

##Physical exam/further imaging:
After reduction, ALWAYS obtain CT. Look for concentric reduction, presence of incarcerated fragments, presence of femoral head or acetabular fracture.
If hip cannot be reduced, it must go to the OR for reduction. 
Call PGY-4 before CT if hip cannot be reduced. Early on, you should probably call PGY-4 before attempting reduction (as long as they can be reached immediately).
DO NOT BREAK THE FEMUR!!
Total Joint Dislocation: For a THA, perform exam and get information about surgeon, number of dislocations. Get plain films.
Call the PGY4 before attempting reduction. The joints attending (e.g. Kraay) may want the PGY4 or chief to do the reduction.

Surgeon, company, implant properties (cemented vs non-cemented, ingrowth vs ongrowth, short vs long stem, fully-coated vs partially-coated)

##Physical exam/further imaging:
Classify fracture: Post-operative Vancouver Classification A, B1-3, C
Assess xrays for any unusual findings:
~~Check thickness of cortical bone. Does the bone look osteopenic? Does the bone look unusually thick? (may require powered reamer)
~~Check for any lesions in the medullary bone. Are there blastic or lytic lesions eating into the cortical bone?
Ask for ambulatory status before injury: 
~~Important for hemi (non-ambulatory) vs THA (ambulatory)
~~Are they active person playing tennis every weekend or do they use a walker to get from couch to bathroom? Alcoholic? Demented? 
~~Pre existing hip/groin pain suggestive of longstanding OA? Pathologic fracture?
Perform appropriate physical exam: Do not need to perform axial load or log roll, just check pulses and motor and sensation distally

##If operative, perform before calling PGY4 and attending:
Mark/Consent for surgery.
Make copy of consent and place original in chart. Make sure to put copy in call room or give it to next call resident.
Keep NPO and NWB.
Find out OR availability: Call to ask for OR availability today and tomorrow.
Ask for clearance:
Refer to pre-operative clearance  guide.
~~ If overnight, call anesthesia.
~~ If during the day and with multiple comorbidities, or for syncopal fall, call medicine.
~~ If trauma activation, call trauma.
~~ If patient goes to ICU, ask for clearance again in morning: These patients have to be reassessed every AM, as their stability may change.
Plan needed implants and operative approach/intervals:
~~Lateral typically vs supine if spine injury on Hana table, with C-arm.
Call reps: Call Stryker or DepuySynthes. All rep numbers in our phone bank.

##Wrap-up:
Call attending: Tell them SBAR, OR schedule
Post case: Tell them name, MRN, attending doing surgery, positioning and operative set-up, implant

##Ask on the phone
Make NPO: Most hip fractures are most likely going to be operative
Ask for labs: CBC, BMP, Coag, Type and Screen (or type and cross for 2 units for hemi), EKG, CXR, Foley, bHCG when appropriate
Ask for proper xrays: 
~~Standard AP/lateral of knee 
~~Get CT, assess for posterior coronal fragment and assess joint congruity

##Physical exam/further imaging:
Classify fracture: Schatzker I-VI
~~Schatzker IV-VI have higher risk of NV compromise. 
~~Medial plateau is normally deeper, which normally keeps the distal femur in its place. This is why with medial plateau injury you must be suspicious for dislocation.
Perform appropriate physical exam, including a detailed vascular exam and ABI:
~~Always get ABI regardless of Schatzkers, it's easy and attendings will ask. Get Dopplers if ABI < 0.8
~~Palpate pulse -> Doppler pulse if not palpable -> get vascular consult and CT angiogram if no Doppler pulse
Perform a careful knee ligamentous stability exam: 
~~Schatzker II -> lateral meniscus tear, Schatzker IV -> dislocation, Schatzker IV-VI -> ACL tear

##Intervention in ED:
Place in knee immobilizer vs long leg splint:
~~For Schatzker I-III, place in WELL-PADDED KI with tons of webroll, even ABDs.
~~For Schatzker IV-VI, basically with any involvement of medial plateau, place in long leg splint to minimize dislocation and rotational instability.

If not shortened, long leg splint: Will need a VERY long leg splint. Posterior/lateral slabs should go proximal to butt. Ace wrap goes around waste. Splint in 10-20 degrees of flexion

##Special Considerations:
Almost all displaced distal physeal femur fractures need operative fixation because of risk of repeat displacement

<u>Indications</u>
• Hip fracture dislocation
• Fracture fragments inside acetabulum on CT
• Unstable hip after reduction (i.e. you check post-reduction CT, and the hip is not concentric)
• Vertical shear pelvic fracture 
• 100% displaced femoral diaphyseal fracture

<u>Steps</u>
• Regardless of indications, always discuss with senior first before initiating skeletal traction
• Find ED charge nurse and have them work on getting a hospital bed; tell them the patient can NOT leave the ED until this happens
• Find trauma/ED resident and nurse taking care of patient to start coordinating sedation
• Call (page?) 30455 yourself to work on getting the bed to the ED (has not worked on the weekends for me)
• Call Materials Management (43401) to have the traction cart brought up to the ED (there may also be traction setups in the Lakeside 60 call room and/or Tower 6 call room)
• Order a portable scout XR of the knee to ensure you aren't about to place traction through a distal femur fx
• Go to the OR and get 2 smooth steinmann pins/wires (2.2mm) which are individually peel packed and on a rack across from rooms 6/7 in the core
• If the patient has a huge leg you may need to open the Synthes 6.5 set to get out the longer 2.8 steinmann pin
• There is also a big metal drawer/tool chest looking thing in the core between OR 6/7, the traction bows are in the bottom drawer, grab one of those. There are also sterile traction bows if you can't find one there
• Get the mini driver and battery x2 (ask the person in the core and they may have you sign it out)
• You can also get a wire cutter for extra style points so you don't leave the sharp tip on the pin after you place it
• In the ED (cabinet in trauma bay is easiest) get sterile gloves, chloraprep, a small scalpel (11 or 15 blade), some kerlix
• Ideally transfer the patient to the hospital bed prior to doing the reduction and placing the traction pin  
• If the bed does not arrive in a timely manner either do the reduction and hang traction off the end of the cart the patient is on, using stacks of blankets to prop up the rope and stabilize the leg; or tape the leg a shit ton to the other leg at the ankle/foot with a blanket in between the ankles
• Place the traction bar setup on the hospital bed (simple frame at the foot of the bed with an extension that you angle off the bed away from the patient at approx 45 deg angle with the pulley at the top for the rope)
• make your rope with loops at both ends, one loop needs to be large enough to fit over the key on the traction bow, the other just attaches to the hook on the weight carrier
• do your reduction of the dislocated hip
• you will often have someone holding traction on the foot for you while you do the next part since you just reduced the hip and it is likely unstable (main reason why you would do this in the first place) 
• if placing skeletal traction through the proximal tibia (not common) make sure to do a full knee ligamentous exam; if unstable, then no traction
• placing blanket bumps under the entire leg will help elevate it so you have more of a straight shot across
• palpate your landmarks on the leg, I like to mark things out (superior aspect of the patella and go 2-3 fingers proximal to that so you're out of the joint)
• prep both the medial and lateral sides of the leg/distal femur; better to over prep so you can feel around and whatnot
• make sure to look how the foot is sitting (int/ext rotation) so that when you pull traction and straighten the leg you don't then realize that you put your pin in at a 30 deg angle
• make a knick in the skin on the medial side; only about 0.5cm (neurovascular structures over the posteromedial femur; which is why you go known to unknown)
• spread down to bone with a hemostat (very small area)
• place pin onto bone and feel the anterior and posterior borders of the femur, you want to center it 
• drive the pin through the bone parallel to the knee joint
• when the pin starts to tent the skin on the lateral side, stop, make another very small knick in the skin, and finish driving the pin through
• alternatively you can just stick the pin straight through skin down to bone and use a hemostat on the lateral side to tension the skin as it starts to poke through. If you do this make sure the skin isn't binding on the pin as your drill it through
• lift the leg up by the pin and make sure it feels like the pin is through bone, and not just muscle/skin
• tension the bow onto the pin by placing the pin ends in the slots and then turning the key on the end of it
• attach the rope to the bow and the weights (usually about 20 lbs for an average adult)
• slowly release manual traction on the leg now that you have the weights in place and make sure that you don't feel the hip slide back out
• snip off the sharp end of the wire and dispose of it properly; you can cover the ends with blood collection tubes or the little sharps cover that comes in the ABG kit (nurse can get this for you)
• wrap the ends of the wire between the bow and the leg with kerlix for padding
• make sure the bow is not resting on the patient's anterior tibia (skin breakdown); may have to pad this with ABDs and/or adjust the angle of the pulley at the end of the bed
• you can either get an AP pelvis to confirm reduction, or go straight to CT if you are confident
• post-reduction CT; will likely have to help transfer the patient and maybe hold the traction while they get the CT
• go see the other 3 consults that piled up while you were doing all that

Daily Schedule 6PM-7PM: Receive sign-out from dayfloat and help them finish up. 7PM-430AM: Consults. 430AM: No matter how busy I am, generally come back up to the callroom to finish email. 5AM: Send email. 545AM: Send group text via DocHalo to Dr. Sontich/Wetzel/Ochenjele about operative traumas. Just send pictures, and I usually copy the HPI/Plan from my call email. They will expect you to know things about cases added on during the day too, so be prepared. 6AM-7AM: Staff your consults with the attendings. Pretty much all of my staffing was via DocHalo. Just send pics/copy call email. 7AM-8AM: Signout to dayfloat, finish up your work. Go to lecture only if all the other stuff is tied up. Who to call and when to “staff” consults (Modified from the guide by Doug Weinberg): This is always confusing for everyone involved. You will probably try to handle as much as you can on your own, without “bothering” as many people as possible. While we can all appreciate this mindset, always know that there is someone more experienced than you available to help. Please note, however, that at the end of the day you have to be the one to staff all of your consults with the attending. We cannot do this for you as we have usually not seen the patient. Therefore, hopefully the following set of rules will assist in efficiently staffing patients: 1) You must staff all patients seen during your call with each attending on call, including ones that had no consults that day for their particular specialty. A DocHalo text or secured email after your call shift or in the morning of night float usually suffices. The morning emails must be sent BY 5AM on weekdays, BY 6AM on weekends so other services can coordinate rounding on the new patients from call. The night emails can be sent a bit later, since services won't be rounding on the new patients, but try to send them out by 6-7pm if you are not getting too crushed. 2) NEVER FEEL BAD ABOUT CALLING THE ATTENDING (no matter what time…) - THEY ARE ON CALL TOO, and they would rather know about the consults than waking up in the morning without that knowledge. 3) While almost all attending’s and residents would prefer a DocHalo or phone call over a page, remember, that paging is still sometimes the best way to reach people emergently, especially in the middle of the night. If you don’t get a response on the phone, and you need an urgent answer, don’t just wait for the attending/senior resident to call back. Stuff happens with cell phones, and some people might not hear a text or call in the middle of the night. Pagers are impossible to ignore. Its super easy to use the UH directory to lookup someone’s pager and type in your page. At the very least, this usually wakes people up enough to have them check their phones. 4) In general, the rules for the other members of the call team (aside from you) are as follows: 1. Attending: Makes all decisions regarding operative consults, makes important decisions on floor patients. 2. PGY5, i.e. the Chiefs: Organizes OR coverage and covers cases they are interested in or needed for. Calls implant reps or assigns it to the PGY4. Chiefs must be aware of all call cases, but should rarely, if ever, be your first call for things that come up while you are on call (at UH at least). Remember that Chiefs are on call essentially every other day, and have a lot of administrative responsibilities as well - try to be respectful of their time, especially when you are at Metro without a PGY4 buffer. While at Metro, you should call the spine fellow/hand fellow/or hand resident for issues on those respective consults. 3. PGY4: Covers cases as assigned by the PGY5, ensures implant availability along with PGY5. They are available to answer questions from PGY2. 5) If there is ever a question of whether “something needs to go to the OR” the attending will ultimately make that decision. The PGY4s on-call are always available to discuss the case first if you are unsure before calling the attending. We would recommend you do so routinely early on in the year, especially during awake hours. Remember, don’t ever feel bad about calling the attendings, as they are on call and ultimately responsible. However, when you do call them make sure you have a clear and succinct story rehearsed in your mind (i.e. SBAR, see below). You should also have a plan (whether right or wrong) and if operative, you need to know the OR availability, NPO time, and medical clearance. You should not serve simply as a reporter. Especially as you move on later in the year, try to take things to the next level and think beyond your training level by considering operative vs. non-op, emergent versus next day, operative technique including approach, positioning, table, instruments and implants. 6) Attendings and seniors often need a picture to help with the decision-making. Take pictures of xrays, important slices on CT/MRI, open wounds and infections so you can securely text them by DocHalo. Don’t send PHI. You can also take videos of CT/MRIs. Always make sure that you get a followup text from the person on the other end to ensure they got your message if it contains critical stuff. 7) A couple hypothetical case examples as follows: EXAMPLE 1: Its 2AM. You get consulted on a patient for flexor tenosynovitis. You see the patient, and determine they have 4/4 Kanavel's signs - something that you can hopefully do without too much assistance. Obviously you realize this is a potentially operative consult. You should start preparing accordingly, get pre op labs (CBC, BMP, Coags, T&S, EKG, CXR if CT Chest not available, urinalysis if hardware to be implanted, b-HCG if appropriate), make sure the patient is NPO, try to get a sense from the OR how busy they are (they may frown upon this, but try to be tactful, because the attending will want to know). At this point, you are ready to staff the consult. Who should you call next? This is a question regarding OR, so you should call the attending. Neither a chief nor PGY4 can tell you it’s ok to “sit on it” with IV ABX until AM, and obviously, they can’t staff a case without an attending. So unless you have a question about the workup/diagnosis, etc., there is no reason to call them at this point. EXAMPLE 2: A patient with a pelvic ring injury comes in. You look at the XR and have no clue what is going on. The XR quality is terrible because the patient is rotated, but it’s the best that they can do because the patient is hemodynamically unstable and crashing in the trauma bay. You are trying to remain calm out but they tell you they just initiated massive transfusion protocol. Apparently Gen Surg is wanting to take patient to OR for an ex-lap. At this point, you are also drowning in other consults, flustered, and not sure if you need to put a pelvic binder. Meanwhile, to fluster you further, some trauma attending shouts at you asking if you are going to put in a traction pin. This is obviously a serious issue, and time is of the essence. Take a deep breath, organize your thoughts, make sure you have x rays, go to a quiet location where you actually have good service, and then call the PGY4. They are available for complicated questions like this, and will direct you accordingly. Ultimately, you will probably end up having to call the attending on this one, but if you are confused about the workup, diagnoses, etc, the PGY4 is there to help you. EXAMPLE 3: A patient comes in with a hip fracture at 2AM. You are able to tell that it is an intertroch fracture with an unstable pattern, you are almost positive that the attending on call the next day is going to want to use an IMN. You complete the workup of the patient, and it seems that this one is straightforward: patient is healthy, no other injuries, really no reason the case couldn’t be cleared for OR in the AM. You even got a manual traction view to help clarify the fracture pattern, and yeah, you were right, this injury is unstable, has some posterior medial comminution and extends sub-trochanteric. You call the trauma anesthesiologist on call to just quickly discuss the case and patient with them. You probably woke them up and you apologize, but you would both agree that it's better for patient care to optimize the patient for the OR. They tell you the case will be cleared for the morning. At this point you finish making sure you have all the appropriate imaging, labs, is marked, consented, and added on. You use your previous Collier Call Worksheet to keep yourself organized, and double check that you haven’t missed anything. While calling the OR control desk, they tell you that the case should be a first start in the trauma room for the morning. Great. At this point, its probably been at least an hour, maybe 3AM right now. You have this patient ready for the AM, you don’t really have any urgent questions that can’t wait a couple hours, and look at you, you even remembered to fill out the pre op HandP, pre op checklist, and put in the XRay order for surgery. You feel great, like a young Mike Tyson. Your only real question is what implant the attending is going to use and who is going to cover the case (maybe even with you doing most of it it since you and your handy Collier worksheet are coming through big time on this one). Although you remember questions like those are above your paygrade, and will have to be addressed by the more important people in the AM, so you take your best guess and tell the OR synthes because that’s what you thought you remembered Dr. Wetzel using for a similar fracture in the past. So you then prepare your signout email for the AM, filling in the blanks from earlier. The chiefs and attendings will want to know about add ons before your email comes out, so you plan on sending the attending a little 545 or 6 AM wakeup DocHalo confirming they want the first start and double checking you got the implant right. However, lucky you, you actually get a text from the attending—half asleep but wondering if they have any cases that day—at 530 AM asking you how the night was and if you added anything on. You then realize they don’t really care how your night was, they are just wondering what they need to do for the day. But no worries, you had your “Collier Call Worksheet” with you all night and the “Napora Common Call Consults” sheet, so you—still covered in sweat and tears—think to yourself “I had a pretty good night last night, thanks for asking.” You then snap back to reality, and either call them or text them details of the case, and go from there. They will usually tell you what implant they want (if they don’t, you must press them for this! or will defer to the chief or PGY4, in which case, make sure you pass along any of that information to the chief/pgy4 involved. Remember, ensuring that a patient gets to the OR appropriately is almost your most important job while on call, all the while making sure your patients are given good care. Communication Dr. Gordon is a big proponent of the SBAR approach to communication. SBAR stands for Situation, Background, Assessment, Recommendation. Below are two examples. Pertinent details only. Keep it simple and concise. Have all of your information available (labs, PMHx, baseline functional status, etc) when you make the call in case you are asked for them. S - “Consult for ballistic diaphyseal femur fracture (vs. with vascular injury)... B - Patient is a 27 year-old otherwise healthy male who presented after single gunshot wound with isolated open neurovascularly intact right comminuted diaphyseal femur fracture...(vs the alternative: no dopplerable signal and CT angio showed transection of femoral artery)... A - Isolated NVI diaphyseal femur fracture in stable patient (vs. Isolated diaphyseal femur fracture with vascular injury requiring urgent repair) R - My plan is IV cefazolin, tetanus, traction pin placement and OR in AM for IMN (vs. IV cefazolin, tetanus, emergent ex fix followed by vascular repair OVN)

"Guide to medicine and anesthesia consult, from Jamie Kyriakedenes:
#1) Cases that will ALWAYS be admitted to medicine - Significant comorbidities that are a constant threat to life and your 'hunch' is that they will require preoperative diagnostics - These can include Echo for CHF that may be decompensating or stress test for new angina, EKG showing RVR or new afib, prolonged hospitalization for recovery from surgery with needs like dialysis, acute hypoxia, needs syncopal workup, etc - Always admit these medically unstable patients to medicine. Think ASA status 3-4. Link to ASA #2) Cases that may be admitted to medicine vs Ortho+Dr.Sidagam* (see below) - Patient has a list of comorbidities, but your hunch is that they are medically stable - These can include well-controlled DM, HTN, CKD, asthma, mild/stable CHF. Blood glucose isn't wildly out of control (not worried about DKA). SysBP isn't 200s. Some baseline SOB without acute worsening. Cr/BUN is somewhat elevated but at baseline, not new this admission. You get the point, think ASA 2-3 patients. - These patients might need additional preoperative diagnostic studies, but it is not every time, thus requires more work-up: * A) You choose to pursue admission to medicine. If you stop there and leave the hospital, the medicine team may not round on this patient until 1 pm, they then realize OSH records are needed, etc may not get around to clearing patient until the afternoon or later. Therefore, if you admit to medicine, personally call the medicine team (obtain pager # from ED) and let them know that we are trying to do the case at 10:00 am (or whatever our attending seems to indicate the order will be- ask chief if questions), and to please round on this patient FIRST, to plan to evaluate and optimize patient by that time, and let us know as soon as possible if they have concerns about the patient's ability to be taken to surgery that morning. Dr. Sidagam can also be involved in this situation, but the medicine attending should request and/or be aware of you involving Dr. Sidagam (per Sidagam). * B) You choose to admit to Ortho and consult Dr. Sidagam for preoperative clearance (+/- postop comanagement). You must then either call Dr. Sidagam around 8:30-9 when he comes in (phone 66867), or CLEARLY sign this task out to the Dayfloat team (or other resident covering that new admission). In this situation (and actually likely either situation 1 or 2 for these sick patients), you would be wise to not expect a 730 first-start, and should temper expectations of the ortho-trauma attending accordingly. #3) Regarding calling anesthesia about a patient preoperatively: You should always call the anesthesiologist on-call overnight when you think a patient needs to go to OR that following MORNING (or you have high suspicion that our attending will try to take patient to OR that morning..) and the patient has one of the ""CARDIAC"" CONDITIONS* below that you feel ""might"" require further workup. We will continue to go back and forth with anesthesia on what is appropriate and what is not appropriate for overnight calls, and our current opinion is that cardiac/cardiovascular/cardiopulmonary issues most often cause delays in cases, and are important for them to start reviewing as soon as possible. Not infrequently, anesthesia may require further workup even though the medicine team ""cleared"" a patient, which may delay the case. These conditions frequently require comparing a current Echo or stress test to a previous Echo or stress test. From now on, please call anesthesia overnight when the patient has one of the CARDIAC CONDITIONS below: * CARDIAC= - heart (congestive heart failure, angina, history of heart attacks, valvular conditions [mitral or aortic regurgitation, aortic stenosis, etc.], arrthymias) - Cardiopulmonary (history of pulmonary embolism) - Cardiovascular (history of abdominal aortic aneurysm or aortic dissection) Misc pre-operative requirements ALL HIP FRACTURE PATIENTS NEED A FOLEY Pediatric patients do not need pre-operative labs (save them from a needle stick!) T&S?? Sugartong = show actual picture, of patient's motion; Short leg splint = neutral flexion, everything gets a splint Bundle consults together before calling Joint aspiration - need lavadner top tubes "

On Ortho Hand Call Days:
• Isolated UE trauma- first dibs goes to Ortho Hand; if more proximal than cutoffs below, staff with Ortho Trauma:
• Malone: all trauma finger to shoulder 
• Anderson: finger to distal humerus
• Khouri: ?
• Polytrauma (multiple orthopaedic surgical injuries)- (NO nerve or tendon injury)- Ortho Trauma gets first dibs and will involve hand team as needed
• Polytrauma (WITH nerve or tendon injury)- Ortho Hand gets first dibs and will involve Ortho Trauma as needed

On Plastics Hand Call Days:
• Diaphyseal forearm and proximal injuries, septic elbow and shoulder*- Ortho Trauma to cover (..if General Ortho on-call defers)
• Distal radius (and more distal injuries if plastics unable to cover)*- first dibs to Ortho Hand attending on call (if covering plastics call) or whoever is on Ortho Hand call the following day 
• Ortho Trauma may elect to cover distal radius if an unstable/polytrauma patient is already in OR
• When plastics is on call, they see pediatric hand issues
• On Friday, 
o If it’s isolated distal radius fx only, it goes to the hand attending on call on Saturday
o If prox to distal radius, it goes to trauma attending on Friday first; can refuse and pass on to hand attending
• On Sunday,
o If it’s isolated distal radius fx, it goes to weekend hand attending; NOT the hand attending on for Monday

*Coverage of other soft tissue consults, finger to axilla, is unchanged- Ortho Hand sees on Ortho Hand call days, Plastics sees on Plastics Hand call days

Pediatric (skeletally immature) UE injury or infection should be first staffed with Peds Ortho attending, who will involve Ortho Hand as indicated

Lets say you get a pulseless knee dislocation that you know needs to go to the OR ASAP. After initial assessment, you need to quickly and carefully plan what you’re going to do next because there are a lot of ways for things to not go efficiently in this scenario.

1. Call your PGY4 ASAP: Its good to get them on board early just for a plan. They can also let the PGY5 know so they can plan to come to the OR if necessary. It is your responsibility to make sure the PGY5 is aware of the case. If the PGY5 tells you that they are not doing the case, and that the PGY4 is doing the case, it is then your responsibility to make sure the PGY4 is aware and updated accordingly with OR times, etc.
2. Talk with the primary team/consulting services: Get a feel for if the patient is clear for the OR, as well as the plans from the other services. For example, Vascular surgery may want to do their repair first before Ortho provides an ex-fix (obviously a bit controversial, but who knows). 
3. Call the OR charge nurse and anesthesia attending: You need to call both people to see if a room is available, and if anesthesia is ok with running the case.
4. Call the Attending: You should call the attending only after you know all of the other prior information. Confirm with the attending what implants they want, and if they want the rep available.
5. Call the Rep: This is something the PGY4 might do, but it is still your responsibility to confirm they do this, or you do it yourself. I talked to the Synthes Head Rep and for anytime Synthes is used, he said to call his cell 24/7. If he isn’t on call, his voicemail will give the contact info for the rep on call. I’m not sure how the call schedule for Stryker works. 
6. Transfer the Patient to the OR: You have to coordinate this with the OR control desk. They will get mad if you bring the patient too early.

General OR set-up equipment

Standard radiolucent OR table: Fracture table: Any type of OR table with boots that allow for rotation and traction control of legs: Used for: - Many long-bone fractures Hana table: Specific fracture table, produced by Mizuho, that allows for hyperextension, adduction, and external rotation of the leg. Used for: - Anterior approach for THA - Hip, femur, tibia fractures – allows for IM nail Jackson frame: Used for: - Most spine surgeries, as it allows prone positioning

Specific implants

DepuySynthes: Trochanteric Fixation Nail: - DepuySynthes website for Gamma nails - Proximal helical blade designed for better resistance to varus collapse - Used for proximal femur fractures - Comes in short and long variants (for extension into diaphysis) Titanium Cannulated Tibial Nail: - DepuySynthes website for tibial nails - For proximal, middle, and distal tibial shaft fractures Stryker: Gamma cephallomedullary nail series: - Stryker website for Gamma nails - Gamma trochanteric nail: short cephalomedullary nail that can be used for femoral neck fractures, intertrochanteric fractures, subtrochanteric fractures - Gamma Long Nail: long cephalomedullary nail that can be used for proximal femur fractures with extension into the femoral diaphysis Recon femoral nail: - Stryker website for Recon nails - Long intramedullary nail with options for 2 lag screws proximally for proximal femur fractures and a distal locking screws for antegrade nailing of diaphyseal femur fractures T2 antegrade/retrograde femoral nail: - Stryker website for Recon nails - Long intramedullary nail with options for 2 lag screws proximally for proximal femur fractures and a distal locking screws for antegrade nailing of diaphyseal femur fractures T2 tibia nail: - Stryker website for T2 tibia nail - For proximal, middle, and distal tibia diaphysis fractures - Can be used for suprapatellar approach Fragment sets: Small fragment set: - Variants from all implant makers (Stryker, DepuySynthes, etc.) - For fixation of fractures, osteotomies, and nonunions of the clavicle, scapula, olecranon, radius, ulna, distal tibia, and fibula, particularly in osteopenic bone Large fragment set: - Variants from all implant makers (Stryker, DepuySynthes, etc.) - For fixation of various long bones, such as humerus, femur, tibia - Buttressing tibial plateau Pelvic recon plate and screws: - Variants from all implant makers (Stryker, DepuySynthes, etc.) - Specifically designed to fit complex anatomy of pelvis
